Generation II.Gold: Its tail is so powerful that it can use it to grab a tree branch and hold itself up in the air.
Generation II.Silver: It lives atop tall trees. When leaping from branch to branch, it deftly uses its tail for balance.
Generation II.Crystal: It uses its tail to hang on to tree branches. It uses its momentum to swing from one branch to another.
Generation II.Stadium 2: Its tail is so powerful that it can use it to grab a tree branch and hold itself up in the air. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) It lives atop tall trees. When leaping from branch to branch, it deftly uses its tail for balance. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation III.Ruby: Aipom 's tail ends in a hand-like appendage that can be cleverly manipulated. However, because the Pok é mon uses its tail so much, its real hands have become rather clumsy.
Generation III.Sapphire: Aipom 's tail ends in a hand-like appendage that can be cleverly manipulated. However, because the Pok é mon uses its tail so much, its real hands have become rather clumsy.
Generation III.Emerald: Its tail ends with a dexterous, handlike appendage. However, because it uses the tail so much, Aipom 's real hands have become rather clumsy.
Generation III.FireRed: It lives atop tall trees. When leaping from branch to branch, it deftly uses its tail for balance.
Generation III.LeafGreen: Its tail is so powerful that it can use it to grab a tree branch and hold itself up in the air.

Generation IV.Diamond: It uses its tail to pluck fruits that are out of reach. Its tail is more adept than its real hands.
Generation IV.Pearl: It lives atop giant trees. It wraps its tail around a branch so it won't fall off while asleep.
Generation IV.Platinum: It lives high among the treetops. It can use its tail as freely and cleverly as its hands.
Generation IV.HeartGold: Its tail is so powerful that it can use it to grab a tree branch and hold itself up in the air.
Generation IV.SoulSilver: It lives atop tall trees. When leaping from branch to branch, it deftly uses its tail for balance.

Generation VI.X: It lives atop tall trees. When leaping from branch to branch, it deftly uses its tail for balance.
Generation VI.Y: Its tail is so powerful that it can use it to grab a tree branch and hold itself up in the air.
Generation VI.Omega Ruby: Aipom's tail ends in a hand-like appendage that can be cleverly manipulated. However, because the Pokémon uses its tail so much, its real hands have become rather clumsy.
Generation VI.Alpha Sapphire: Aipom's tail ends in a hand-like appendage that can be cleverly manipulated. However, because the Pokémon uses its tail so much, its real hands have become rather clumsy.

Generation VII.Ultra Sun: As it did more and more with its tail, its hands became clumsy. It makes its nest high in the treetops.
Generation VII.Ultra Moon: It searches for prey from the tops of trees. When it spots its favorite food, Bounsweet, Aipom gets excited and pounces.

Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: It uses its tail to pluck fruits that are out of reach. Its tail is more adept than its real hands.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: It lives atop giant trees. It wraps its tail around a branch so it won't fall off while asleep.
Generation VIII.Legends: Arceus: This treetop dweller possesses a tail as dexterous as a hand. Ancient writings describe this Pokémon as a one-armed oddity.

Generation IX.Scarlet: It lives atop of trees. When leaping from branch to branch, it deftly uses its tail for balance.
Generation IX.Violet: Its tail moves with greater dexterity than its hands. Making deft use of this tail, Aipom lives high among the treetops.
